TEXT.English: [TAB]Historically, the Bedouin engaged in nomadic herding, agriculture and sometimes fishing. A major source of income was the taxation of caravans, and tributes collected from non-Bedouin settlements. They also earned income by transporting goods and people in caravans across the desert. Scarcity of water and of permanent pastoral land required them to move constantly.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Moroccan traveller, Ibn Battuta, reported that in 1326 on the route to Gaza, the Egyptian authorities had a customs post at Qatya on the north coast of Sinai. Here bedouin were being used to guard the road and track down those trying to cross the border without permission.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Early Medieval grammarians and scholars seeking to develop a system of standardizing the contemporary Classical Arabic for maximal intelligibility across the Arabophone areas, believed that the Bedouin spoke the purest, most conservative variety of the language. To solve irregularities of pronunciation, the Bedouin were asked to recite certain poems, whereafter consensus was relied on to decide the pronunciation and spelling of a given word.
TEXT.Chinese: 历史上，贝多因人从事游牧、农业，有时还从事渔业。收入的一个主要来源是对大篷车征税，以及从非贝多因人定居点征收的贡品。他们还通过在沙漠中用大篷车运送货物和人员赚取收入。由于缺水和永久性的牧场，他们必须不断迁移。[第2段]摩洛哥旅行者伊本・巴图塔（Ibn Battuta）报告说，在1326年前往加沙的途中，埃及当局在西奈北部海岸的Qatya设立了一个海关哨所。贝多因人在这里被用来守卫道路，追踪那些未经允许试图越境的人。[第2段]中世纪早期的语法学家和学者试图开发一个标准化当代古典阿拉伯语的系统，以便在阿拉伯文地区实现最大的可懂度，相信贝多因人说的是最纯正、最保守的语言。为了解决发音不规则的问题，贝多因人被要求背诵某些诗歌，然后根据一致意见来决定给定单词的发音和拼写。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Janissaries were an elite fighting force of infantry raised by the Ottoman sultans. They formed the sultan's household troops and bodyguard, eventually rising to a position of enormous influence before being disbanded in the nineteenth century. Murad I founded the Janissary corps around 1330; the troops were made up of non-Muslim boys who were captured in battle or bought as slaves and brought up as warriors. This was very similar to the Mameluk slave soldiers of Egypt, who may have been the inspiration for the Janissaries. Janissaries became the first infantry units in the Ottoman military forces, because at the time no free man would consent to fighting on foot. [PARAGRAPH:2]After 1380 the system for recruiting new soldiers into the Janissaries became standardized through a process called the "devshirmeh:" this was basically a "human tax" where each community had to contribute a certain number of young boys to the state. In practice these were almost always Christian slaves. [PARAGRAPH:2]The boys were sequestered in special barracks, where they would be converted to Islam and trained to become elite soldiers (a process very similar to that practiced by the Spartans of ancient Greece). Although slaves, the Janissaries received special privileges, including the right to bear weapons and higher pay than other soldiers. Although the Janissaries began their existence as a small bodyguard for the sultan, in time they came to comprise much of the Ottoman army, topping out at over 200,000 men at some points. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Janissaries originally were trained to be expert archers, but once firearms were invented they quickly adopted the new weapons, becoming fiercely proficient with muskets. They usually used axes or sabres for melee combat. Janissaries were present at all of the major battles in the early history of the Ottoman Empire, including the Siege of Constantinople in 1453. [PARAGRAPH:2]The very success of the Janissaries would eventually destroy them. Realizing their importance, they began demanding higher pay, threatening rebellion if their demands were refused. Their first rebellion took place in 1449, and it was followed by many more. By the eighteenth century, the Janissaries dominated the government. Through frequent palace coups they changed sultans as they wished, and they blocked much-needed modernization reforms in the Ottoman army. Many of the Janissaries became corrupted, no longer training for battle but instead pursuing commercial ventures or political office, and the weakness of the Ottomans in the face of Russian and Austrian expansion soon became obvious to all. Desperate to regain control of their country, the Ottoman rulers made determined efforts to eradicate them. [PARAGRAPH:2]Finally, in 1826 Mahmud II was able to form a non-Janissary army strong enough to challenge the Janissaries. The Janissaries did not go down peacefully, and Mahmud II had to use artillery to shell the Janissaries' barracks and batter them into submission. This event - known as the "Auspicious Incident," ended the Janissaries. Their characteristic marching music is the only trace of them that remains today.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]禁卫军是奥斯曼苏丹培养的一支精锐步兵战斗部队。他们组成了苏丹的家庭军队和保镖，最终在19世纪解散之前，上升到一个具有巨大影响力的地位。穆拉德一世在1330年左右建立了“Janissary军团”；这支部队由非穆斯林男孩组成，他们在战斗中被俘虏，或被当作奴隶收买，然后被当作战士抚养长大。这与埃及的马梅鲁克奴隶士兵非常相似，他们可能是Janissaries的灵感来源。日军成为奥斯曼帝国军队的第一批步兵，因为当时没有一个自由人愿意步行作战。[第2段]1380年后，通过一个称为“devshirmeh”的程序，在Janissaries招募新士兵的制度变得标准化：这基本上是一种“人类税”，每个社区都必须向国家贡献一定数量的男孩。实际上，这些人几乎都是基督教奴隶。[第2段]这些男孩被隔离在特殊的营房里，在那里他们将皈依伊斯兰教，并接受训练成为精英士兵（这一过程与古希腊斯巴达人的做法非常相似）。虽然是奴隶，但是日本的卫戍区享有特殊的特权，包括携带武器的权利和比其他士兵更高的薪水。尽管禁卫军最初是作为苏丹的一个小保镖而存在的，但后来他们组成了奥斯曼帝国的大部分军队，在某些时候超过了20万人。[第2段]Janissaries最初被训练成弓箭手专家，但一旦发明了火器，他们很快就采用了新武器，对步枪变得非常熟练。他们通常使用斧头或刀进行近战。在奥斯曼帝国早期历史上的所有重大战役中，包括1453年对君士坦丁堡的围攻中，都曾出现过禁卫军。[第2段]一月的成功最终会摧毁他们。意识到自己的重要性，他们开始要求更高的工资，威胁说如果他们的要求被拒绝，他们就会造反。他们的第一次叛乱发生在1449年，随后又发生了更多的叛乱。到了18世纪，政府由禁卫军统治。通过频繁的宫廷政变，他们如愿以偿地更换苏丹，并阻止了奥斯曼军队急需的现代化改革。许多禁卫军变得腐败，不再为战斗训练，而是追求商业冒险或政治职位，奥斯曼帝国在俄罗斯和奥地利扩张面前的弱点很快就变得显而易见。奥斯曼统治者急于夺回对自己国家的控制权，决心铲除他们。[第2段]最后，在1826年，马哈茂德二世组建了一支强大到足以挑战一月制的非一月制军队。卫戍军并没有和平地倒下，马哈茂德二世不得不用大炮炮击卫戍军的军营，并将他们击溃投降。这一事件被称为“吉祥事件”，结束了一月。他们特有的行军音乐是他们今天仅存的踪迹。
